ODOM: They would be worse off if we left.
They cannot operate in Kurdistan now.
The Shiites don't like them and don't cooperate with them.
The Sunnis cooperate with them because they happen to be a convenient ally who will kill Sunnis and try to stir up a civil war.
Kill Shias (unintelligible).

ODOM: I mean, kill Shias and stir up a civil war.
The training they're getting here that they've not gotten before is actual combat, and we've seen the recruitment go up dramatically.
After 9/11 and the invasion of Afghanistan, recruitment for al-Qaida dropped precipitously for about 18 months.
Coming up, the McCain Girls.
Is that some kind of joke?
But first, Wednesday night, Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama met in Philadelphia for their 21st debate of the campaign season.
Most polls show the two Democratic candidates about a half-dozen points apart as they head into the important and possibly decisive Pennsylvania primary on Tuesday.
Terry Madonna is director of the Center for Politics and Public Affairs at Franklin and Marshall College in Lancaster, Pennsylvania.
He also directs their poll and joins us from the studios of member station WYTF in Harrisburg.
Thanks so much for being with us, Terry.
Hey, thanks for having me, Scott.
What issues seem to be most important to most Pennsylvania voters?
Oh, I don't think there's any doubt about it - in over the last couple of months, the economy has just increased in importance with each passing month.
We now have somewhere between four and five of 10 voters, 40 or 50 percent of the voters, who say the economy is the most important.
And you know, they're down into, Scott, some nitty-gritty.
I mean, it's gasoline prices, it's concern about rising health care costs, it's are we going to take the vacation this summer?
I mean, things that folks actually talk about when they're sitting around the table, you know, having a meal.
And it's been rising, as I said, and I think it's going to dominate the fall campaign, too.
You know, Iraq will be important, but that's remained pretty static.
It's the economy without doubt.
Does that seem to drive any more voters to one candidate or another on the Democratic side?
Yeah.
Well, Hillary Clinton generally leads when, you know, we ask voters of their vote choice, what issue, you know, are you casting your vote for.
She leads.
Obama's done a little better of late.

But both candidates have really gotten into what I'd call bread-and-butter issues, not esoteric, not the big government programs but really down-to-earth suggestions, and I think that's really helped them.
Have you done any polling that would suggest either candidate benefited from the debate this week?
No, we have not.

And I don't think the debate managed to move many voters, if any, but I don't think the debate, without a headline grabber, without a mistake or without some new position that they articulated that got a lot of press that really was much influence at all on the election in Pennsylvania.
I'm told there are 275,000 people newly eligible to vote in the Democratic primary.
Correct.
Is it your feeling that they are strongly attracted to one candidate or another or just want to be where the action is?
No, we actually surveyed that in our poll.
We asked folks who registered or transferred from independent and Republican to Democrat - we call them switchers - since January, January to March 24, and here's what we found.
Sixty-two percent of them say they'll vote for Senator Obama.

Terry, to put you on the spot a bit, do you see this, as we head into next Tuesday, an election that's a close contest between two candidates or an election in which the question will be what is the size of Senator Clinton's margin…
…yeah.
…of victory or the number of delegates she gets?
I think the latter - and the number of delegates probably don't matter as much.
Under almost any scenario of the 157 delegates at stake, Scott, she can probably only win 12 to 15 more than he does under the proportionality rules.
There'll be a big debate about the size of her victory if she wins.
Now, if she loses, and there's an outside chance - I don't think that will happen - but if she were to lose, I think the nomination contest is over.
If she wins by 9, 10, 11 percentage points, I think she will go out of here saying hey, it was Texas, Ohio, Pennsylvania, I'm on a roll.
Hang in with me.
And the real problem, in a sense, for the race, the contest, is what happens if it's in the, what I call the mushy middle, five, six, seven.
They'll both declare victory, and the race continues.
Terry Madonna, professor of politics and public policy at Franklin and Marshall College, thanks so much.
Hey, thanks for having me.
From NPR West and Slate magazine online, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
Coming up, violent street protests shake the South American nation of Bolivia.
But first, to the global problem of climate change.
Today's New York Times reports that a senior Bush administration official has repeatedly edited government reports to soften the links between greenhouse gases and global warming.

And yesterday, British Prime Minister Tony Blair tried unsuccessfully to convince President Bush to sign on to the Kyoto agreement reducing emissions, but the president says his administration is tackling the problem.
Anbar, and especially in recent weeks its capital Ramadi, has been the scene of some of the bloodiest battles of the war.
Americans come under attack daily in Ramadi as they struggle to bring the city under some sort of control.
Quit tripping.
Don't party yet.
You ain't home.
You look like you're free, right?
You guys think you're free, huh?
You get to wear your own clothes.
Woke up with a beautiful woman, ain't that right?
Yeah.
You had breakfast.
You was able to go 50 miles.
Whoopee, 50 miles - you're almost free.
Don't get it twisted.
You're in a four-step incarceration.
You ain't free yet.
Owens tries hard to get them to focus on the difficult road ahead -find a place to live, a place to work, money to eat, and do it without drugs.
It ain't nobody - it ain't the police fault.
It ain't the parole's fault.
It ain't nobody's fault.
It's your fault.
Anytime you wind up bending over and spreading your cheeks, buck naked, stripping for somebody else, you made a mistake.
The mistake many of these parolees made was doing or selling drugs in the '80s and '90s.
Many of them were the first targets of harsh new drug penalties - prisoners of the war on drugs.
In the years since, few have had rehabilitative programming, drug counseling, job training or education.
Owens says he has seen some of these men and women before, and he will likely see them again.
Seventy percent will be back in prison within three years.
All the big, major drug dealers, they're coming home now - you know, legendary heroes, so to speak.
These guys want their turf back.
And that's causing a conflict between the young drug dealers and the older convicts.
And they're having shootouts on the streets.
(Soundbite of car engine)
It's ""The Untouchables"" all over again.
We're in East Oakland at 73rd and International Boulevard.
This is like one of the hot spot areas in terms of crime and violence.
Junious Williams is a community activist who's lived here since the 1980s.
When you look around this street, there are a lot of beauty shops that are closed up - a liquor store, a retail store that's been turned into a church.
So you get out of prison and you've got $200 in your pocket, you stand on this corner, what do you do?
They've had a lot of problems in this neighborhood, and, in fact, in this intersection, with violence.
We saw a bunch of young men just sort of hanging.
We've got this assumption.
He or she is going to come out, and they're going to get to work.
Well, even in fantasyland, if I had a job, I ain't going to get paid Friday.
So, you know, we put them in a very vicious cycle.
Three to 4,000 inmates are coming home to Oakland every year.
Most return to this rundown neighborhood on the edge of the city - many to this very corner.
Even if you take the most conservative estimate - that's about 3,000 or so folks coming out - we don't have 3,000 substance abuse slots.
We don't have 3,000 jobs.
We don't have 3,000 of anything.
It's beginning to show.
Three years ago, Oakland had 82 murders.
Last year, it had 143.
In those years, the number of inmates returning from prison exploded.
And it's not just Oakland.
Baltimore, Houston, Detroit, St. Louis -dozens of other places are scrambling to provide re-entry services for thousands of former convicts.
But there was a time when many of these former convicts wouldn't have been convicts at all.
In the early 1980s, drugs were illegal, but over the next two decades, California alone added more than 1,000 new drug offenses.
The more drug-related crimes that we put on our books, by definition, we're criminalizing more people, and the crime rate goes up simply because we've defined more people to be criminals.
Daniel Abrahamson is a lawyer who has been involved in trying to reform California's drug laws.
One of the key aspects of the drug war is we've marginalized entire populations and subcommunities within our nation.
Some of the sentences were staggering.
A two-week supply of crack cocaine would get you a mandatory five years.
That's the same amount of time on average people spend in prison in this country for murder.
